item.title: PNG Lewas celebrate hard-fought victory over UAE in ICC Women’s ODI series
item.description:
Cricket Papua New Guinea proudly congratulates the PNG Lewas on their hard-fought three-wicket win against the United Arab Emirates Women in today’s ICC Women’s ODI Series match 2 at Amini Park, Port Moresby.

After winning the toss and electing to field, the PNG Lewas delivered a disciplined bowling performance to dismiss the UAE for 143 runs in 45.4 overs. Senior bowler Henao Thomas led the attack with a brilliant spell of 4 wickets for 28 runs from her 10 overs, while experienced all-rounder Pauke Siaka was equally impressive with 4 wickets for 39 runs.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNG Lewas celebrate hard-fought victory over UAE in ICC Women’s ODI series appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Obituaries for October 15
item.description: Richard Keonaona Case Sr., 94, of Waimea died Aug. 10 at Queen’s North Hawaii Community Hospital. Born in Kohala, he was a retired heavy equipment operator for the state Highways Division, a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints Waimea 2nd Ward and Waimea Hawaiian Civic Club, and a U.S. Marine Corps veteran. Visitation 10-11 a.m. Saturday (Oct. 18) at the Waimea Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Memorial service at 11 a.m. Lunch to follow. Casual attire; no flowers. Survived by wife, Camille Case of Waimea; sons, Richard K. (Helda) Case Jr. of Las Vegas, Neal K. (Evelyn) Case of Waimea and Jason K. K. (Ammy) Case of Waikoloa; daughters, Flora K. (Oscar) Bueno of Honokaa, Camille K. (Howard) Kent of Waimea and Lynn A. (Dominic) Regidor of Honolulu; brothers, Lloyd (Lani) Case of Waimea and Norman Case of Hilo; sister, Piilani Case of Honolulu; 20 grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren; cousins, nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.
item.source:markdown: Richard Keonaona Case Sr., 94, of Waimea died Aug. 10 at Queen’s North Hawaii Community Hospital. item.title: Pennsylvania man pleads guilty to arson attack on governor’s mansion
item.description: A 38-year-old man pleaded guilty on Tuesday to attempting to murder Democratic Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro in an April arson attack on the governor’s residence in which he scaled a fence and ignited part of the house with gasoline-filled beer bottles as Shapiro and his family slept inside.
item.source:markdown: A 38-year-old man pleaded guilty on Tuesday to attempting to murder Democratic Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro in an April arson attack on the governor’s residence in which he scaled a fence and ignited part of the house with gasoline-filled beer bottles as Shapiro and his family slept inside.

item.title: US news outlets reject Pentagon press access policy
item.description: WASHINGTON — At least 20 news organizations declined to sign a new Pentagon access policy for journalists, warning of the potential for less comprehensive coverage of the world’s most powerful military ahead of a Tuesday deadline to accept new restrictions.

item.title: Airports refuse to show video of Kristi Noem blaming Democrats for shutdown
item.description: More than a dozen airports across the country are refusing to display a video of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem blaming Democrats for the government shutdown and any travel disruptions that may result from it. Representatives for the airports said that the video was overly partisan.

item.title: EHCC exhibition embodies body politics
item.description: Human bodies, and the relationships we have to our own bodies and the way that others present their bodies to us, are complex. Seven artists offer us their unique perspectives on the questions inherent in these relationships at East Hawaii Cultural Center’s new exhibition, “Em-bodied. Body Politics,” on view now through Nov. 26.
item.source:markdown: Human bodies, and the relationships we have to our own bodies and the way that others present their bodies to us, are complex. Body Politics,” on view now through Nov. 26.

item.description:
The Arawa Skills Training Centre (ASTC) is now Bougainville’s newest institution, specializing in heavy equipment training for local youths.

The indigenous, all-Bougainville creation marked Tuesday, October 14th, as the day the ribbon was officially cut to open the new classroom and conduct the students’ orientation.

item.title: Australia tripling HIV investments in PNG
item.description:
In response to the surge in HIV cases in Papua New Guinea, Australia will nearly triple its investment to fight the virus in the country from 2025 to 2026.

This was revealed by Australian Senator Nita Green, who was in the country earlier this week to officiate the opening of the Australian-funded refurbishment of the St. Therese HIV clinic in Hohola, Port Moresby.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Australia tripling HIV investments in PNG appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: High flying in the Central highlands
item.description:
Flight training in the Central highlands for pilots and aircrew of the Australian Defence Force is winding down as the visiting 5th Aviation Regiment turns its attention to supporting the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) during Exercise Wantok Warrior.

Around 100 ADF personnel and four CH-47F Chinook helicopters have conducted daily flights around the Owen Stanley Ranges as part of Exercise Helicon Luk 2025, an annual activity aimed at getting pilots and aircrew qualified to fly at altitude and in mountainous terrain.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post High flying in the Central highlands appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: NRL slams down 10-year ban on players, agents engaging with unrecognised competitions
item.description:
The Australian Rugby League Commission (ARLC) has delivered a forceful blow to rival leagues, today announcing a sweeping new policy that threatens 10-year bans for any NRL player or accredited agent who negotiates with or signs for a competition not recognised by the ARLC.

The decisive sanctions, released following an ARLC meeting on Wednesday, October 15, 2025, come in direct response to the increasing threat posed by rebel competitions—reportedly including the emerging R360 league—which the ARLC accuses of attempting to "exploit" and "pirate" the game's talent for financial gain.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post NRL slams down 10-year ban on players, agents engaging with unrecognised competitions appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Peter-Vlandys-AM.jpg?w=800)
The Australian Rugby League Commission (ARLC) has delivered a forceful blow to rival leagues, today announcing a sweeping new policy that threatens 10-year bans for any NRL player or accredited agent who negotiates with or signs for a competition not recognised by the ARLC.
The decisive sanctions, released following an ARLC meeting on Wednesday, October 15, 2025, come in direct response to the increasing threat posed by rebel competitions—reportedly including the emerging R360 league—which the ARLC accuses of attempting to "exploit" and "pirate" the game's talent for financial gain.

item.title: O panikeke le mafua’aga na misa ai se ulugalii
item.description:
[ata: foa'i]
By 
LALI STAFF

Pago Pago - AMERIKA SAMOA

O le taeao o le aso 27 o Aukuso, 2025, na valaau atu ai se tina loto mafatia i le ofisa a leoleo ma talosagaina se fesoasoani ina ua sauaina o ia e sana uo tama i luma o lana fanau.

[Ua le lomia suafa o i latou na a’afia ma molia i lenei fa’alavelave, ona o le puipuiga o le tina na a’afia ma le fanau iti.]

Ina ua taunu’u leoleo i le nofoaga na tupu ai le faalavelave ma feiloai ma le tina na a’afia, sa maitauina le ma’osia o itu uma o le ua a le tina na a’afia, ae na  tele i lona itu taumatau.

Sa faasino iai e le tina na a’afia, i leoleo, ia lana uo tama o lo’o i totonu o lona potu.  Na maua atu e leoleo, o lo’o ta’oto’oto le na molia, i totonu o le potu, ma ave faapagotaina ai o ia ma tu’u i totonu o le taavale a leoleo, ae liliu ane leoleo, i le fesiligia ia le tina na a’afia.

E tusa ai ma le faamatalaga a le tina na a’afia, e le fa’atasi ona sauaina o ia e lana uo tama.  Sa ia ta’ua i leoleo ia le fa’atele ona osofa’ia o ia e lana uo tama i taimi ua tuana’i.

Sa faamalamalama e le tina na a’afia, ia le fa’alavelave na tupu i lea taeao, a fai sana falai panikeke mo lana fanau iti e to’atolu ma sa lava ai na’o latou e to’atolu.  Ae alu atu le na molia ma fesili i le tamaititi matua (e fa tausaga), pe mafai ona ‘ai sana panikeke.  

Ma sa fa’asaga loa ia le na molia, i le ‘ai ia panikeke a le fanau, ma totoe ai na’o ni nai panikeke.

E le gata i lea, sa ta’ua e le tina na a’afia, le alu atu o lona uso laititi ma mana’o i se panikeke, ae sa tali le tina na aafia, o panikeke mo na’o le fanau iti.  Ma sa faatonu e le tina na a’afia ia lona uso laititi, a fia mana’o i se panikeke, alu e falai sana panikeke.  Ae peitai, na oso atu le na molia ma fai atu i le uso laititi, e alu e ai sana panikeke.

O iina na otegia ai loa e le tina na a’afia ia lana uo tama ma fai iai, i le leai o sana galuega o faia, ae na’o le moe.  Ona savali atu lea o le tina na a’afia ma saofa’i i lalo, i tafatafa o lana tamaiaititi e 2 tausaga, ae savali atu le na molia ma palauvale atu ia te ia ma tatu’i lona ulu, a’o si’i e le tina lana tamaititi i lona lima.

Sa ta’ua foi e le tina, lona u’uina mai o se la’au, ina ua ta’oto i lalo ia le na molia, ma amata ona ia sasaina ai komepiuta feavea’i (laptops) le fanau, ona o lona ita tele.

Ae oso mai le na molia ma u’u le tina mai tua ma titina lona ua.  Sa faailoa atu e le tina na a’afia, i leoleo, le amata ona ia tau le mafai ona manava ma na ia taumafai malosi e ave’ese lima o le na molia, se’ia o’o ina u’u e le na molia ia lona pui manava ma si’i o ia i luga, ae togi i lalo o le foloa sima.

Sa ta’ua e le tina le tau i lalo o tua o lona ulu ma fula ai tua o lona ulu.  O lona ‘e’e leotele, na feosofi mai ai tagata o lona aiga.

Na faamatala e le ‘aunty’ a le tina na a’afia, i leoleo, sa ia lagonaina le ‘e’e leotele a le tina na a’afia, mai i totonu o le latou potu.  Ma na ia alu atu ma aumai i fafo le fanau iti e to’atolu sa iai i totonu.

Sa ave uma e leoleo, i ta’avale ‘ese’ese, ia le tina na a’afia ma le na molia, i le ofisa a leoleo.

Ma ina ua fa’atalanoaina e leoleo ia le na molia, sa ia fa’amaonia le faia o se la tauga’upu ma le tina na a’afia, ona o panikeke a le fanau ma sa ia ‘e’e ma palauvale i le tina na a’afia.  Sa ia ioe foi i lona taumafai e titina le ua o le tina.  Ae peitai, sa o la tau fai pa’u’u uma i lalo.  Ma na iai uma le fanau i le taimi na tupu ai le faalavelave.

E 5 faitauga o moliaga sa faia faasaga i le na molia, na aofia ai:

Faitauga 1:  Faatupu Vevesi i nofoaga tuma’oti – O se vaega ‘C’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala i le o’o atu i aso e 15, po o se sala tupe e $300; po o faasalaga uma e lua.

Faitauga 2:  Fa’ao’olima i lona tulaga e tolu – O se vaega ‘A’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala i le o’o atu i le tausaga atoa po o se sala tupe e $1,000; po o faasalaga uma lua.

Faitauga 3, 4 & 5:  Faia o se gaioiga e a’afia ai le saogalemu o fanau iti – O se vaega ‘A’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala i le o’o atu i le tausaga atoa po o se sala tupe e $1,000; po o faasalaga uma lua.

E $3,000 se vaegatupe na fa’atulagaina e mafai ona tatalaina ai i tua le na molia, a’o faagasolo lona faamasinoga.

item.source:markdown:
[![](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/asg_dps_badge_13.jpg?itok=j8h1u8pF)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/asg_dps_badge_13.jpg?itok=hP2-ETnC)
> \[ata: foa'i\]
By
LALI STAFF
Pago Pago - AMERIKA SAMOA
O le taeao o le aso 27 o Aukuso, 2025, na valaau atu ai se tina loto mafatia i le ofisa a leoleo ma talosagaina se fesoasoani ina ua sauaina o ia e sana uo tama i luma o lana fanau.
\[Ua le lomia suafa o i latou na a’afia ma molia i lenei fa’alavelave, ona o le puipuiga o le tina na a’afia ma le fanau iti.\]
Ina ua taunu’u leoleo i le nofoaga na tupu ai le faalavelave ma feiloai ma le tina na a’afia, sa maitauina le ma’osia o itu uma o le ua a le tina na a’afia, ae na tele i lona itu taumatau.
Sa faasino iai e le tina na a’afia, i leoleo, ia lana uo tama o lo’o i totonu o lona potu. Na maua atu e leoleo, o lo’o ta’oto’oto le na molia, i totonu o le potu, ma ave faapagotaina ai o ia ma tu’u i totonu o le taavale a leoleo, ae liliu ane leoleo, i le fesiligia ia le tina na a’afia.
E tusa ai ma le faamatalaga a le tina na a’afia, e le fa’atasi ona sauaina o ia e lana uo tama. Sa ia ta’ua i leoleo ia le fa’atele ona osofa’ia o ia e lana uo tama i taimi ua tuana’i.
Sa faamalamalama e le tina na a’afia, ia le fa’alavelave na tupu i lea taeao, a fai sana falai panikeke mo lana fanau iti e to’atolu ma sa lava ai na’o latou e to’atolu. Ae alu atu le na molia ma fesili i le tamaititi matua (e fa tausaga), pe mafai ona ‘ai sana panikeke.
Ma sa fa’asaga loa ia le na molia, i le ‘ai ia panikeke a le fanau, ma totoe ai na’o ni nai panikeke.
E le gata i lea, sa ta’ua e le tina na a’afia, le alu atu o lona uso laititi ma mana’o i se panikeke, ae sa tali le tina na aafia, o panikeke mo na’o le fanau iti. Ma sa faatonu e le tina na a’afia ia lona uso laititi, a fia mana’o i se panikeke, alu e falai sana panikeke. Ae peitai, na oso atu le na molia ma fai atu i le uso laititi, e alu e ai sana panikeke.
O iina na otegia ai loa e le tina na a’afia ia lana uo tama ma fai iai, i le leai o sana galuega o faia, ae na’o le moe. Ona savali atu lea o le tina na a’afia ma saofa’i i lalo, i tafatafa o lana tamaiaititi e 2 tausaga, ae savali atu le na molia ma palauvale atu ia te ia ma tatu’i lona ulu, a’o si’i e le tina lana tamaititi i lona lima.
Sa ta’ua foi e le tina, lona u’uina mai o se la’au, ina ua ta’oto i lalo ia le na molia, ma amata ona ia sasaina ai komepiuta feavea’i (laptops) le fanau, ona o lona ita tele.
Ae oso mai le na molia ma u’u le tina mai tua ma titina lona ua. Sa faailoa atu e le tina na a’afia, i leoleo, le amata ona ia tau le mafai ona manava ma na ia taumafai malosi e ave’ese lima o le na molia, se’ia o’o ina u’u e le na molia ia lona pui manava ma si’i o ia i luga, ae togi i lalo o le foloa sima.
Sa ta’ua e le tina le tau i lalo o tua o lona ulu ma fula ai tua o lona ulu. O lona ‘e’e leotele, na feosofi mai ai tagata o lona aiga.
Na faamatala e le ‘aunty’ a le tina na a’afia, i leoleo, sa ia lagonaina le ‘e’e leotele a le tina na a’afia, mai i totonu o le latou potu. Ma na ia alu atu ma aumai i fafo le fanau iti e to’atolu sa iai i totonu.
Sa ave uma e leoleo, i ta’avale ‘ese’ese, ia le tina na a’afia ma le na molia, i le ofisa a leoleo.
Ma ina ua fa’atalanoaina e leoleo ia le na molia, sa ia fa’amaonia le faia o se la tauga’upu ma le tina na a’afia, ona o panikeke a le fanau ma sa ia ‘e’e ma palauvale i le tina na a’afia. Sa ia ioe foi i lona taumafai e titina le ua o le tina. Ae peitai, sa o la tau fai pa’u’u uma i lalo. Ma na iai uma le fanau i le taimi na tupu ai le faalavelave.
E 5 faitauga o moliaga sa faia faasaga i le na molia, na aofia ai:
Faitauga 1: Faatupu Vevesi i nofoaga tuma’oti – O se vaega ‘C’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala i le o’o atu i aso e 15, po o se sala tupe e $300; po o faasalaga uma e lua.
Faitauga 2: Fa’ao’olima i lona tulaga e tolu – O se vaega ‘A’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala i le o’o atu i le tausaga atoa po o se sala tupe e $1,000; po o faasalaga uma lua.
Faitauga 3, 4 & 5: Faia o se gaioiga e a’afia ai le saogalemu o fanau iti – O se vaega ‘A’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala i le o’o atu i le tausaga atoa po o se sala tupe e $1,000; po o faasalaga uma lua.
E $3,000 se vaegatupe na fa’atulagaina e mafai ona tatalaina ai i tua le na molia, a’o faagasolo lona faamasinoga.

item.title: TALA I VAIFANUA
item.description:
[ata: foa'i]
By 
LALI STAFF

Pago Pago - AMERIKA SAMOA

TOE FO’I SUAESE “POOCH” TAASE I LONA TOFIGA SA IAI

O le aso 6 o Oketopa, 2025, na sainia ai e le Faatonusili o le Ofisa o A’oga a le malo, le susuga ia Maefau Dr. Mary Taufete’e, ia se tusi, e aloaia ai se fa’ai’uga a le latou ofisa, e toe fa’afo’i ai le susuga ia Suaese Pooch Taase, i lona tofiga sa iai muamua, o le Faatonu o le Ofisa o Ta’aloga a le Ofisa o A’oga.

I fa’aupuga o le tusi a le Tama’ita’i Faatonu, sa ia auiliiliina ai sini fa’atuina, o tiute ma matafaioi, ua mana’omia ona ausia e “Pooch”, i lona toe tula’i mai i le foe

O Setema 24, 2025 sa ave’esea ai “Pooch” mai lona tofiga fa’aleta’ita’i, ae fa’ase’e atu o ia e avea ma faiaoga o ta’aloga ma le soifua maloloina, i le aoga maualuga a Leone.  Ona o lenei suiga sa faia, a’o feagai Pooch ma se fete’ena’iga o manatu ma le tamaitai Faatonu o A’oga, ona o ni suiga sa faia i totonu o lana aufaigaluega. 

E tusa ai ma le taofi a Pooch, ua mafua ona faia nei suiga, ona o lona fa’atu’i’ese i nisi o fa’ai’uga a le Faatonu o Aoga, lea o loo ia taofi, o le a avea ma a’afiaga i polokalama a lona ofisa.

Ina ua fa’atula’i ‘ese ia Pooch, sa faapea ona filifilia ia le susuga ia Tulaga Kevin Magalei e avea ma Faatonu fou o Ta’aloga a a’oga uma o le malo.

PASIA E LE SENATE IA DOUGLAS BUHR E AVEA MA SUI O LE KOMITI FAAFOE A LE ASPA

Ua pasia nei e le Maota o le Senate, ia le filifiliga o le susuga ia Douglas Buhr, e avea ma se tasi o sui o le Komiti Faafoe o Faatonusili, a le Matagaluega o le Eletise ma le Suavai (ASPA), ina ua o latou palotaina o ia 10 ioe – 2 leai, i le taeao o le aso Lulu, o le vaiaso ua mavae.  

O le susuga ia Buhr, o se tasi o sui e to’alua, a lenei komiti fa’afoe, o lo’o aumau i atunu’u i fafo ma o lona agava’a ma lona tomai fa’ainisinia, ua mafai ona filifilia ai o ia.

O Buhr, o le peresetene ma inisinia sinia a le kamupani, o le Douglas Engineering Pacific Inc., lea e faamautu i Hawaii.  Ua silia ma le 40 tausaga o galue o ia i totonu o galeuga fa’aeletise ma o se tasi, ua loa ona galue ma mafana se mafutaga ma Amerika Samoa, talu mai poloketi e tele i le 1998.

I lona iloiloga i luma o le komiti a le ASPA a le Senate, i le taeao o le aso Lulu, Oketopa 8, 2025, sa toe tomanatu ai Buhr, i le ulua’i taimi na taunu’u mai ai i Amerika Samoa, i le 1998, e avea ma se faufautua i se poloketi sa faia i le suavai lafoa’i i Malaloa.  O le ulua’i poloketi foi lea, i le tele o poloketi mo le faaleleia o le teritori, sa galue ai lenei sui.

Ae o se galuega e pito a luga i le loto ma le mafaufau o Buhr, o le avea lea o ia ma se faufautua tomai faapitoa mo le ASPA, ina ua mae’a le galulolo tele i le 2009.  O ia sa ta’ita’ia ni vaega sa o latou iloiloga tulaga ua fa’aleagaina i afi tetele a le ASPA i Satala, ae le gata i lea, o lona lagolago malosi i le manumalo a le ASPA i se faamasinoga mo inisiua ma le ofia a le Lloyd’s i Lonetona.

Sa fa’aleoina e Buhr i lona iloiloga i le aso Lulu, na filifilia o ia e avea ma sui o le komiti faafoe a le ASPA, e le susuga ia Ted Le’iato – o se tasi o tagata muamua na o la fa’amasani i le ASPA, ina ua fa’ato’a amata ona galue ai.

I sana tali i se fesili a le Afioga i le Peresetene o le Senate, le Tofa ia Tuaolo Manaia Fruean, sa faamaonia ai e Buhr, le faavaeina o le filifiliga a Le’iato, i lona agava’a fa’ainisinia faapea ana galuega fa’afaifeau.  E le gata i le avea o ia ma Peresetene o le kamupani i Hawaii, ae o lo’o avea foi o ia (Buhr) ma fa’afeagaiga o se ekalesia Penetekoso i Iapani.

Ina ua fesiligia o ia, po o ai sa totogia lona pasese e malaga mai ai, e auai i lona iloiloga, sa tali Buhr, sa pau lava le tulaga na fa’ailoa atu ia te ia, o lona auai mai lea ae na te le o mautinoa, po o le ASPA, po o le malo sa totogia lana faimalaga mai.  Na faamanino e Tuaolo, e na’o sui o le komiti faafoe, ua mae’a ona pasia, e mafai ona totogi e le ASPA a latou femalagaiga.

O fesili a le Afioga i le Senatoa ia Togiola T.A. Tulafono, na fa’atatau i le soifua galue a Buhr, lea e na te umia ai laisene fa’ainisinia i Hawaii, Kalefonia, Illinois ma Oregon.

O le fesili a le Afioga i le Senatoa ia Olo Uluao Letuli ia Buhr, na ia fia malamalama ai i le malamalama’aga a le sui fa’aolioli, i le misiona ma lu’itau o lo’o feagai ma le ASPA, ma po o le a fo’i se tulaga o lo’o mafai ona ia aumaia, e fesoasoani i faafitauli o feagai ma le ASPA, i le taimi nei.

Na saunoa Buhr, e le’i fa’ailoa atu ia te ia, ni fa’afitauli o feagai ma le ASPA, ae o ia o se faifeau, o se tagata e taumafai aumai faatasi uma tagata.  E ui ina ‘ese’ese manatu, ae e tatau lava ona manatua, e tasi le mauga o lo’o iai.  O tatou o ni vaega o se tagata e tasi, ma e tatau ona taumafai e aumai uma tagata i se malamalama’aga e tasi.

Sa fa’aleoina e Olo le iai o sona faamoemoega, o le a mafai ona galue tutoatasi ma le faamaoni, le sui fa’aolioli.  Ae le o se tagata na ona ‘ioe’.  Ma sa fa’amamafaina foi e le afioga i le Senatoa, le manaomia o sui o le komiti faafoe ina ia fa’amuamua le mamalu lautele, ona o le toatele o tagata o le atunu’u, o lo’o mafatia i le taugata o le tau o le eletise.

MOLIA SE ALII I LONA SAUAINA O SE TAMAITITI TALAVOU NA MANA’O I LANA MATA TIOATA

O le afiafi o Aukuso 24, 2025, e tusa ai ma fa’amaumauga a le faamasinoga, na valaau atu ai se tamaitai mai i Taputimu, i le Ofisa a Leoleo i Leone, e ripotia ia se alii, ua na sauaina lona ‘nephew’,  e 16 tausaga le matua.

O le na molia e tuaoi ma le alii talavou na a’afia.

Ina ua taunu’u leoleo i le nofoaga na tupu ai le faalavelave, sa faamatalaina iai e le tamaitai na valaau i le ofisa a leoleo, e tusa ai ma le faamatalaga a le alii talavou na a’afia, na ona fesiligia lona uso laititi, po o feal ana mata, ae fai mai lona uso laititi, na ave e se tamaloa e latou te tuaoi.

O se taimi mulimuli ane, na fetaui ai le alii talavou na a’afia ma le na molia, i fafo o le fale a le na molia.  Ma na fesili iai le alii talavou po o fea lana mata, lea sa ia (le na molia) ave’esea mai lona uso laititi.  Ae ita le na molia ma tago u’u atu le ofu a le alii talavou na a’afia ma po ona foliga, ae fa’ai’u i le tu’i.

Sa tamo’e le alii talavou i le latou aiga ma faamatala i lona ‘aunty’ le mea sa tupu, ma vala’au ai loa le aunty i le ofisa a leoleo.

Sa taumafai leoleo e saili le na molia, i lea aso, ae sa le’i maua o ia.

Ae na molia o ia i moliaga o le Fa’ao’olima i lona tulaga muamua ma le Faia o se gaioiga e a’afia ai le saogalemu o fanau talavou.

O nei moliaga, o ni vaega ‘A’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala ai i le falepuipui, e o’o atu i le ta’I tasi tausaga i le moliaga, po o se sala tupe e ta’i $1,000; po o faasalaga uma e lua.

E leai se tupe na fa’atulagaina e mafai ona tatalaina ai le na molia, a’o fa’agasolo lona faamasinoga.

Section: 
Le Lali

O le afiafi o Aukuso 24, 2025, e tusa ai ma fa’amaumauga a le faamasinoga, na valaau atu ai se tamaitai mai i Taputimu, i le Ofisa a Leoleo i Leone, e ripotia ia se alii, ua na sauaina lona ‘nephew’, e 16 tausaga le matua.
O le na molia e tuaoi ma le alii talavou na a’afia.
Ina ua taunu’u leoleo i le nofoaga na tupu ai le faalavelave, sa faamatalaina iai e le tamaitai na valaau i le ofisa a leoleo, e tusa ai ma le faamatalaga a le alii talavou na a’afia, na ona fesiligia lona uso laititi, po o feal ana mata, ae fai mai lona uso laititi, na ave e se tamaloa e latou te tuaoi.
O se taimi mulimuli ane, na fetaui ai le alii talavou na a’afia ma le na molia, i fafo o le fale a le na molia. Ma na fesili iai le alii talavou po o fea lana mata, lea sa ia (le na molia) ave’esea mai lona uso laititi. Ae ita le na molia ma tago u’u atu le ofu a le alii talavou na a’afia ma po ona foliga, ae fa’ai’u i le tu’i.
Sa tamo’e le alii talavou i le latou aiga ma faamatala i lona ‘aunty’ le mea sa tupu, ma vala’au ai loa le aunty i le ofisa a leoleo.
Sa taumafai leoleo e saili le na molia, i lea aso, ae sa le’i maua o ia.
Ae na molia o ia i moliaga o le Fa’ao’olima i lona tulaga muamua ma le Faia o se gaioiga e a’afia ai le saogalemu o fanau talavou.
O nei moliaga, o ni vaega ‘A’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala ai i le falepuipui, e o’o atu i le ta’I tasi tausaga i le moliaga, po o se sala tupe e ta’i $1,000; po o faasalaga uma e lua.
E leai se tupe na fa’atulagaina e mafai ona tatalaina ai le na molia, a’o fa’agasolo lona faamasinoga.

item.title: TALA MAI SAMOA
item.description:
[ata: foa'i]
By 
LALI STAFF

Apia - SAMOA

TOE FA’ASE’E I TUA TAGI FAASAGA I LE FOFOGA FETALAI

Ua toe fa’ase’e i tua, e le susuga ia Mulipola Leiataualesa Laki, ia lana tagi sa faia faasaga i le Fofoga Fetalai o le Palemene, le susuga ia Auapaau Mulipola Aloitafua.

Na talosagaina e le Pulenu’u a Salua, se tasi afioaga o itumalo a Mulipola ma Auapa’au, ia le faamasinoga, ina ia toe fa’aleaogaina ia le tagi, ona o i la’ua e mai i le afioaga e tasi, ma e latou te va’ai mamalu ma aloaia ai le Fofoga Fetalai o le palemene.

Ma sa faapea ona toe fa’ase’e uma i tua ia tagi a itu uma e lua, faapea le fautuaina o i la’ua ina ia fa’asalalauina se fa’aaliga e fa’alauiloa ai le faia o lea tulaga ma o le aso 23 o Oketopa, o le a fofogaina ai lenei mataupu i luma o le faamasinoga, ma e mana’omia ona fa’aali ai se kopi o lea fa’aaliga, i luma o le faamasinoga.

A’o alo atu le faamasinoga i lenei mataupu, ae o le taimi lava lea e tasi o lo’o iloiloina ai i isi potu faamasino, nisi foi tagi e lua, mai i tagi e valu sa faaulu, talu mai le mae’a o le palota.  Ua iai se ripoti e faapea, o le a fa’ase’e foi i tua le tele o nei tagi, na afua mai i le palota lautele a le atunu’u, ia Aukuso 29.

FAUTUAINA E LE PSC IA LE TOE FA’ASALALAUINA O LE TOFIGA O LE KOMESINA A LEOLEO

I le fa’ai’uga a le Kapeneta i le vaiaso ua tuanai, mo le fa’amutaina o le faaopoopoga o le konakarate a le Komesina o Leoleo, le susuga ia Auapaau Logoitino Filipo, sa faavaeina i se ripoti mai i le Komisi o Auaunaga mo le Lautele (PSC), ina ia toe amatalia ona fa’asalalauina le avanoa mo nisi e fia apalai mai iai.

Ina ia o gatasi ma le fautuaga a le PSC, ua maea le faagasologa o le ulua’i sailiga ma ua toe amataina, ina ia fa’amautuina le nofo malamalama o le mamalu lautele, faapea ma le tatalaina o le avanoa, i le mamalu lautele.

O le konakarate a Auapa’au, sa faamutaina, ae sa toe soso’oina e le kapeneta ua mavae atu, se’ia mae’a galuega a le PSC mo le sailiga o se Komesina fou.

Ae o le taimi nei, ua filifilia e le Kapeneta ia le susuga ia Leiataua Samuelu Afamasaga, lea o lo’o mataituina ia auaunaga mo falepuipui, e avea ma sui Komesina a leoleo.

O le vaiaso ua tuanai, na tu’ua ai e Auapa’au lona ofisa.

TALITALIA E SAMOA IA FAIGAMALAGA A LE NGAHIRAKA WAKA MAI AOTEAROA, NIU SILA

O se taimi o le taeao nei, o lo’o ua faamoemoe, e taunu’u ai i Samoa ia le faigamalaga a le ‘aumalaga a le Ngahiraka Waka mai Te Kura Waka Aiga Folau, i Tauranga, Aotearoa i Niu Sila, ma o lo’o ua nofo tapenapena mai le Aiga Folau Samoa, e latou te fa’afeiloa’i lenei faigamalaga su’esu’e.

Na fa’aalia e le Peresetene o le Aiga Folau Samoa, le susuga ia Leota Fitimaula Donna Aiono Le Tagaloa Ioane, ia le agaga fiafia e fa’afeiloai i le Aiga Folau mai Aotearoa.  

Na tu’ua e le Ngahiraka ia Niu Sila mo Samoa, ia Setema 25, 2025 ma o lo’o fa’atautaia e se ‘auva’a e to’avalu, e fa’aaogaina I a le tomai o na ona po, e tautai ai le latou folauga, e pei o le matagi, o le la, o fetu, masina, o ao, o galu ma gogosina.

Ae peitai, ona o tulafono mo le nofo puipuia, ua mae’a ona tu’uina i totonu o le va’a ia nisi foi o masini faaneiona po, ina ia mautu ai le taunu’u saogalemu o le faigamalaga.

Section: 
Le Lali

The exchange took place outside court […]

The post Police calm down verbal confrontation outside court  appeared first on Talamua Online.
item.source:markdown:
By Lagi Keresoma/ Apia, Samoa – 15 October 2025 – Police had to intervene to calm down a heated verbal exchange when a village representative appealed to petitioner Leaana Ronnie Posini to withdraw his petition against the Minister of the Environment, Seve Tei Fuimaono of the Safata 1 constituency. The exchange took place outside court \[…\]

item.title: Peter Norman Colton, OBE
item.description:
Peter leaves behind an extraordinary legacy spanning over six decades of service to Papua New Guinea. Born on August 22, 1943, on the Scotland-England border and raised in South Wales, Peter's journey to becoming one of PNG's most dedicated adopted sons began when his family emigrated to Australia in 1953 as part of the "Ten Pound Pom" scheme.

The post Peter Norman Colton, OBE appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Biometric election in 2027, not possible
item.description:
AT this age and time when technology is available anywhere in the world to undertake any task, whether big or small, with ease and in a short space of time, we are still talking about using a biometric system in our national general election.

How will this conversation end and how long this will take is anybody’s guess but from what we know, it will take more than a commitment from the Prime Minister James Marape.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Marape commends radio station for promoting positive values and Youth Empowerment
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has commended Wantok Radio Light for its enduring role in spreading positive, faith-based messages across Papua New Guinea, describing it as an “instrument of hope” that uplifts hearts and guides young people toward productive and meaningful lives.

Speaking during a visit to the Wantok Radio Light studios on the occasion of its 24th anniversary, Prime Minister Marape highlighted the vital importance of media that nurtures the moral and spiritual wellbeing of the nation.

item.title: PNG host women leaders for pacific women leaders in Tennis workshop
item.description:
Eleven women from across the Pacific have arrived in Papua New Guinea for the Pacific Women Leaders in Tennis initiative. Delivered by the Australian Government’s PacificAus Sports program in partnership with Tennis Australia, the program supports emerging Pacific women leaders in tennis administration with leadership modules and mentoring, empowering participants to take the next steps in their careers.

This year’s cohort includes Adelaide Senior and Abilgail Tere-Apisah from PNG and other participants from Fiji, Marshall Islands, Nauru, Tonga, Samoa, Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNG host women leaders for pacific women leaders in Tennis workshop appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Obituaries for October 14
item.description: Dominic Stephen Apollo, 59, of Kapaau died Sept. 22 at Queen’s North Hawaii Community Hospital in Waimea. Born in Cleveland, he was a concierge for Hilton Waikoloa Beach Resort. Visitation 9 a.m.-10 a.m. Saturday (Oct. 18) at Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Hawi. Mass at 10 a.m. Burial to follow in Hawi County Cemetery. Casual attire; flowers welcome. Survived by wife, Virginia Apollo of Kapaau; daughter, Jennifer Apollo of Hilo; sister, Selene Martinez of California. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: How the United States is eating Trump’s tariffs
item.description: FRANKFURT/WASHINGTON — U.S. companies and consumers are bearing the brunt of the country’s new import tariffs, early indications show, contradicting assertions by President Donald Trump and complicating the Federal Reserve’s fight against inflation. Trump famously predicted that foreign countries would pay the price of his protectionist policies, wagering that exporters would absorb that cost just to keep a foothold in the world’s largest consumer market.
item.source:markdown: FRANKFURT/WASHINGTON — U.S. companies and consumers are bearing the brunt of the country’s new import tariffs, early indications show, contradicting assertions by President Donald Trump and complicating the Federal Reserve’s fight against inflation. Trump famously predicted that foreign countries would pay the price of his protectionist policies, wagering that exporters would absorb that cost just to keep a foothold in the world’s largest consumer market.

item.title: The very hungry microbes that could, just maybe, cool the planet
item.description: UNDER THE TYRRHENIAN SEA, Italy — Fifty miles off the Tuscan coast, in a sparkling blue expanse broken only by rocky, forbidding islets, including the real-life Island of Montecristo, ancient creatures are roosting beneath the waves.

item.title: Heavy rains flood Mexico towns, leave nearly 130 dead or missing
item.description: MEXICO CITY — Torrential rains that lashed Mexico last week killed at least 64 people and 65 more are missing, the government said on Monday, after a tropical depression triggered landslides and flooding in parts of the Gulf Coast and central states.
item.source:markdown: MEXICO CITY — Torrential rains that lashed Mexico last week killed at least 64 people and 65 more are missing, the government said on Monday, after a tropical depression triggered landslides and flooding in parts of the Gulf Coast and central states.

item.title: Military troops set to miss first paycheck since US shutdown started
item.description: WASHINGTON — The financial impacts of the government shutdown are set to escalate this week, even as Senate Republicans and Democrats show no signs of breaking the stalemate over health care policies at the heart of the fight.

item.title: After record crypto crash, a rush to hedge against another freefall
item.description: NEW YORK — Following the largest crypto liquidation in history last Friday, options market investors are bracing for more volatility and further declines in bitcoin and ether, aggressively positioning in trades that offer protection against another potential freefall.
item.source:markdown: NEW YORK — Following the largest crypto liquidation in history last Friday, options market investors are bracing for more volatility and further declines in bitcoin and ether, aggressively positioning in trades that offer protection against another potential freefall.

item.title: WHO warns of sharp increase in drug-resistant infections
item.description: Around the world, the spread of dangerous infections that do not respond to antibiotics has been increasing by as much as 15% a year, affecting treatment for urinary tract infections, gonorrhea, E. coli and other pathogens that kill millions of people annually, according to a report released Monday by the World Health Organization.
item.source:markdown: Around the world, the spread of dangerous infections that do not respond to antibiotics has been increasing by as much as 15% a year, affecting treatment for urinary tract infections, gonorrhea, E. coli and other pathogens that kill millions of people annually, according to a report released Monday by the World Health Organization.

item.title: SpaceX launches another Starship rocket to test reusable design
item.description: WASHINGTON — Elon Musk’s SpaceX launched its 11th Starship rocket from Starbase, Texas on Monday, a test mission to demonstrate the giant vehicle’s reusable design for lofting satellites and eventually taking humans to the moon and Mars.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Elon Musk’s SpaceX launched its 11th Starship rocket from Starbase, Texas on Monday, a test mission to demonstrate the giant vehicle’s reusable design for lofting satellites and eventually taking humans to the moon and Mars.

item.title: Madagascar’s president has left the country after Gen Z protests, officials say
item.description: ANTANANARIVO — Madagascar’s president Andry Rajoelina has fled the African nation, the head of the opposition, a military source and a foreign diplomat said on Monday, the second time that young protesters have toppled a government in just over a month of worldwide Gen Z unrest.
item.source:markdown: ANTANANARIVO — Madagascar’s president Andry Rajoelina has fled the African nation, the head of the opposition, a military source and a foreign diplomat said on Monday, the second time that young protesters have toppled a government in just over a month of worldwide Gen Z unrest.

item.title: North Carolina Republicans plan to redraw congressional map to add a seat
item.description: Republican lawmakers in North Carolina announced plans Monday to redraw the state’s already gerrymandered congressional maps to further favor their party. It’s the latest effort to help the Trump administration retain control of the U.S. House in the midterm elections next year.

item.title: Five weeknight dishes: Quick and customizable burrito bowls and more
item.description: I’ve written before about the modular meal, a “cook once, feed many” approach that leaves everyone satisfied, even — gasp! — happy. For this, as for many things, I am indebted to Julia Moskin, who years ago canonized this approach and its merits: “Dishes like this are adaptable to many life stages, like the children’s furniture systems that supposedly allow you to turn a crib into a bed, then into a desk, and finally into a pair of chic reading glasses.”
item.source:markdown: I’ve written before about the modular meal, a “cook once, feed many” approach that leaves everyone satisfied, even — gasp! — happy. For this, as for many things, I am indebted to Julia Moskin, who years ago canonized this approach and its merits: “Dishes like this are adaptable to many life stages, like the children’s furniture systems that supposedly allow you to turn a crib into a bed, then into a desk, and finally into a pair of chic reading glasses.”

item.title: Let’s Talk Food: ’Growing Up Hapa in Hawai‘i’ cookbook
item.description: More than just a cookbook, ‘Growing Up Hapa in Hawai‘i’ is a celebration of heritage, resilience, and the power of connection. Chef Ippy Aiona, with a local Hawaiian father and an Italian mother, shares the flavors and traditions that define his upbringing in the picturesque town of Waimea.

item.title: Premiership winner Brendan Piakura ready for Cook Islands return in PNG
item.description:
Brisbane Broncos premiership-winning forward Brendan Piakura has arrived in Papua New Guinea, switching his focus from NRL glory to international duty with the Cook Islands team for the Pacific Championships.

Fresh off the back of the Broncos' first premiership in 19 years, Piakura spoke about the emotional whirlwind of the last few weeks and his eagerness to pull on the national jersey once more after a long hiatus.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Bati captain Tui Kamikamica backs young guns to win Pacific Bowl
item.description:
Fiji Bati captain Tui Kamikamica is banking on a blend of veteran experience and exciting young talent to spearhead Fiji’s campaign to win the 2025 Pacific Bowl Championship, starting this Sunday against a strong Cook Islands Aitus side.

Kamikamica is confident in the squad’s mixture of old and new faces, viewing the tournament as a vital step for the Bati’s long-term future.

item.title: Australia expands support for HIV services in Papua New Guinea
item.description:
The Australian government is nearly tripling its investment in HIV services in Papua New Guinea (PNG), following the PNG Government’s declaration of a HIV emergency in June this year.

Working in partnership with the PNG Government, churches, the private sector, and others, Australia is increasing its annual HIV development funding to almost $10 million this financial year to safeguard the Papua New Guinean population.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Australia expands support for HIV services in Papua New Guinea appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Australia-expands-support-for-HIV-services-in-Papua-New-Guinea-1.png?w=800)
The Australian government is nearly tripling its investment in HIV services in Papua New Guinea (PNG), following the PNG Government’s declaration of a HIV emergency in June this year.

item.title: ‘Thirty-five too old,’ PNG’s definition of youth raises Questions
item.description:
In Papua New Guinea, the term “youth” is officially defined as individuals aged between 15 and 35, a range that many see as unusually broad and inconsistent with how the term is used globally.

The PNG National Research Institute (NRI) says the lack of a standardised definition across government and institutional sectors is creating confusion and policy challenges.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post ‘Thirty-five too old,’ PNG’s definition of youth raises Questions appeared first on Post Courier.

In Papua New Guinea, the term “youth” is officially defined as individuals aged between 15 and 35, a range that many see as unusually broad and inconsistent with how the term is used globally.

item.title: Senisim PNG program certified 87 University students with leadership certificates
item.description:
A TOTAL of 87 university students graduated under Senisim PNG Program as certified facilitators of the leadership program with PNG Tribal Foundation since July of this year.

Tribal Foundation graduated 42 from Institute of Business University graduated as the highest, 38, University of Papua New Guinea and seven from University of Pacific Adventist.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Senisim PNG program certified 87 University students with leadership certificates appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Seth-Jackson-Chief-Technical-Officer-of-the-MRA-Working-Committee-14.png?w=800)
A TOTAL of 87 university students graduated under Senisim PNG Program as certified facilitators of the leadership program with PNG Tribal Foundation since July of this year.
Tribal Foundation graduated 42 from Institute of Business University graduated as the highest, 38, University of Papua New Guinea and seven from University of Pacific Adventist.

item.title: Industry calls for strategic bottom-up plan to sustain PNG Agriculture
item.description:
The Government is urged to set a proper bottom-up plan and strategies on how to grow agricultural commodities sustainably, in partnership with the private sectors on the ground, to boost the national economy going forward.

Land is the key to growing the economy and minimizing unemployment; yet, the government is doing very little to sustain both existing and new tree crop plantations and boost the economy over time.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Industry calls for strategic bottom-up plan to sustain PNG Agriculture appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Chairman-PNG-Coffee-Plantations-and-Processors-Association-PNGCPPA-Mr-Albert-Wamiri-urge-government-to-intervene-and-save-plantation-owners-and-farmers-involving-in-various-agricultural-commod.png?w=800)
The Government is urged to set a proper bottom-up plan and strategies on how to grow agricultural commodities sustainably, in partnership with the private sectors on the ground, to boost the national economy going forward.
Land is the key to growing the economy and minimizing unemployment; yet, the government is doing very little to sustain both existing and new tree crop plantations and boost the economy over time.
To access this post, you must purchase [Web](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/product/web/) or [Web & eBook](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/product/web-ebook/).

item.title: First female recipient of ‘Georgina Kiele Scholarship’
item.description:
The Department of Information and Communications Technology (DICT) and the Australian Government have announced Ms Georgina Yarra from Telikom PNG as the inaugural recipient of the Georgina Kiele Scholarship for Women in Cybersecurity, awarded under the Australia Awards program.

Ms Yarra will pursue a Master of Information Technology (Cyber Security) at Adelaide University in Australia. The scholarship includes professional development, mentoring, and networking opportunities, with support from industry partners such as CyberCX, Vocus, and Oracle.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post First female recipient of ‘Georgina Kiele Scholarship’ appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Nita-Green.png?w=800)
The Department of Information and Communications Technology (DICT) and the Australian Government have announced Ms Georgina Yarra from Telikom PNG as the inaugural recipient of the Georgina Kiele Scholarship for Women in Cybersecurity, awarded under the Australia Awards program.
Ms Yarra will pursue a Master of Information Technology (Cyber Security) at Adelaide University in Australia. The scholarship includes professional development, mentoring, and networking opportunities, with support from industry partners such as CyberCX, Vocus, and Oracle.
To access this post, you must purchase [Web](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/product/web/) or [Web & eBook](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/product/web-ebook/).

item.title: Bill proposed to ease restrictions on recruitment of foreign medical graduates to Guam
item.description: Sen. Telo T. Taitague has introduced a bill seeking to alleviate Guam’s longstanding shortage of physicians and specialists by expanding licensure pathways for foreign medical graduates, streamlining credentialing processes and establishing a Guam Conrad 30 J-1 Physician Waiver Program.
item.source:markdown: Sen. Telo T. item.title: Awareness on sorcery violence needed
item.description:
The beliefs in sorcery and related practices are apart and parcel of life in this country.

Many studies have analysed these practices in our communities and in particular the negative consequences of these traditional belief systems and the reports from these studies show our people believe sorcerers are people who act unconsciously and are driven by the urge to cause sickness, death or bring misfortunes and other terrible events upon others.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Awareness on sorcery violence needed appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Ok Tedi and National Energy Authority partner to accelerate rural electrification
item.description:
Ok Tedi Mining Limited (Ok Tedi) and the National Energy Authority (NEA) have a signed a Memorandum of Agreement to advance the Lighting Up the West (LTW) initiative, a transformative program aimed at expanding access to reliable, affordable, and clean energy across Western, West Sepik, and East Sepik Provinces.

The MoA, signed by Ok Tedi Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer Kedi Ilimbit, and NEA Managing Director Ronald Meketa, establishes a framework for regulatory cooperation, licensing, and stakeholder engagement to deliver rural electrification through decentralised renewable energy (DRE) solutions in the short- to medium-term, and hydropower in the long[1]term.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Ok Tedi and National Energy Authority partner to accelerate rural electrification appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Biz-1-8.png?w=800)

The MoA, signed by Ok Tedi Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer Kedi Ilimbit, and NEA Managing Director Ronald Meketa, establishes a framework for regulatory cooperation, licensing, and stakeholder engagement to deliver rural electrification through decentralised renewable energy (DRE) solutions in the short- to medium-term, and hydropower in the long\[1\]term.

item.title: Cybercrime Act enforcement spark controversy after fixed bail imposed
item.description:
The National Capital District’s police have sparked a significant debate after the Metropolitan Superintendent, Warrick Simatab, announced a tough new stance on cybercrime, ordering a mandatory K5,000 fixed bail for all offenders charged under the Cybercrime Act.

This measure, aimed at curbing online defamation, misinformation, and digital abuse, has drawn immediate criticism, with legal experts and politicians arguing the law’s intent is being distorted to protect the powerful.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Cybercrime Act enforcement spark controversy after fixed bail imposed appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/TOP-3-6.png?w=800)
The National Capital District’s police have sparked a significant debate after the Metropolitan Superintendent, Warrick Simatab, announced a tough new stance on cybercrime, ordering a mandatory K5,000 fixed bail for all offenders charged under the Cybercrime Act.
This measure, aimed at curbing online defamation, misinformation, and digital abuse, has drawn immediate criticism, with legal experts and politicians arguing the law’s intent is being distorted to protect the powerful.

item.title: Urgent search underway for missing student after island party in Madang
item.description:
A search operation is underway in Madang, in the waters off Kranget, Bilia, Siar, and Pik Island for a male student, Elison Nobi from Biwat, who resides at Meiro, after he went missing early Saturday morning following a birthday party on an island next to Kranget.

 The disappearance of Elison, who had recently arrived from Lae, comes as a local rescue effort successfully brought over 80 students to safety after a massive island party, highlighting the dangers of late-night sea travel in the area.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Urgent search underway for missing student after island party in Madang appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Guam Waterworks Authority completes installation of dieldrin-treatment system at Yigo well
item.description: By Pacific Island Times News Staff The Guam Waterworks Authority has installed its interim treatment system at a dieldrin-contaminated well in Yigo, completing the first step toward the eventual rescission of the “do not drink without treatment” advisory issued to 1,112 customers. “With the installation of this treatment system, our community can be assured that the water supply meets all federal and local drinking water standards while we continue working toward our long-term solution...
item.source:markdown: By Pacific Island Times News Staff The Guam Waterworks Authority has installed its interim treatment system at a dieldrin-contaminated well in Yigo, completing the first step toward the eventual rescission of the “do not drink without treatment” advisory issued to 1,112 customers. “With the installation of this treatment system, our community can be assured that the water supply meets all federal and local drinking water standards while we continue working toward our long-term solution...

item.title: Partisan shutdown standoff ignores key risk to US stability: rising national debt
item.description: WASHINGTON — The ongoing shutdown debate between Democrats and President Donald Trump’s Republicans is largely avoiding the difficult fiscal issues clouding the country’s future - the rising national debt and the long-term financial health of Social Security and Medicare. The fifteenth partial federal government shutdown since 1981 has been sparked by Democrats’ demand for spending, which would cost about $1.5 trillion over the next decade according to the nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, adding to the nearly $38 trillion national debt.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The ongoing shutdown debate between Democrats and President Donald Trump’s Republicans is largely avoiding the difficult fiscal issues clouding the country’s future - the rising national debt and the long-term financial health of Social Security and Medicare. The fifteenth partial federal government shutdown since 1981 has been sparked by Democrats’ demand for spending, which would cost about $1.5 trillion over the next decade according to the nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, adding to the nearly $38 trillion national debt.

item.title: Some Americans are starting to feel the impact of the government shutdown
item.description: WASHINGTON — Reverberations of the federal government shutdown, which began nearly two weeks ago, are starting to be felt by certain segments of Americans, hinting at problems that could deepen for the public if Congress cannot reach a funding agreement soon.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Reverberations of the federal government shutdown, which began nearly two weeks ago, are starting to be felt by certain segments of Americans, hinting at problems that could deepen for the public if Congress cannot reach a funding agreement soon.

item.description: Kindergarten vaccination rates in Hawaii continue to lag behind the national average, according to the latest data from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

item.title: Ironwoman: Lovseth surprises, clinches first Ironman World Championship

item.title: Jaxon Smith-Njigba continues hot start as Seahawks down Jaguars
item.description: Jaxon Smith-Njigba kept his sensational season going with a season-high 162 receiving yards, leading the Seattle Seahawks to a 20-12 win over the host Jacksonville Jaguars Sunday afternoon.

item.title: Hawaii minimum wage to rise by $2 in 2026
item.description: Hawaii workers earning minimum wage will see the state’s biggest pay bump in years when the new rate takes effect on Jan. 1, 2026, jumping from $14 to $16 per hour — an increase of $2 that outpaces most other states.

item.title: Trump heads to Israel and then Egypt as hostage-prisoner swap nears
item.description: President Donald Trump left Washington on Sunday afternoon, heading to Israel to meet with hostage families today and then address the Knesset. He is then scheduled to travel to Egypt, where he and President Abdel Fattah el-Sissi will lead a summit to discuss the peace process in the Gaza Strip with more than 20 countries.

item.title: Vance says ACA credits fuel fraud as Democrats push for extension to end shutdown

item.title: Trump has not ruled out invoking Insurrection Act to deploy National Guard, Vance says
item.description: Vice President JD Vance said on Sunday that President Donald Trump was “looking at all of his options” to deploy the National Guard in major cities, including invoking the Insurrection Act of 1807, which grants the president emergency powers to deploy troops on U.S. soil during major unrest.

item.title: Climate tipping points are being crossed, scientists warn ahead of COP30
item.description: COPENHAGEN — Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected with the world’s coral reefs now in an almost irreversible die-off, marking what scientists on Monday described as the first “tipping point” in climate-driven ecosystem collapse. The warning in the Global Tipping Points report by 160 researchers worldwide, which synthesizes groundbreaking science to estimate points of no return, comes just weeks ahead of this year’s COP30 climate summit being held at the edge of the Amazon rainforest in Brazil.
item.source:markdown: COPENHAGEN — Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected with the world’s coral reefs now in an almost irreversible die-off, marking what scientists on Monday described as the first “tipping point” in climate-driven ecosystem collapse. The warning in the Global Tipping Points report by 160 researchers worldwide, which synthesizes groundbreaking science to estimate points of no return, comes just weeks ahead of this year’s COP30 climate summit being held at the edge of the Amazon rainforest in Brazil.

item.title: If Trump brings war to Chicago streets, chaos will come for us all

item.title: Feeling fed up isn’t a flaw — it’s fuel
item.description: So many of us watch the news, see the attacks on our democracy, and wonder what more we can do. We know that protests are critically important, but few of us see the value of going inside and building relationships with elected officials. “Why would I do that?” we might ask. “Why would it matter?” Here’s one example.

item.title: Leave Portland alone
item.description: “Portland is burning to the ground,” President Donald Trump warns, and he has helpfully explained that it is a “war-ravaged” hellscape where even the mayor and governor are “petrified for their lives.” Trump purports to be trying to rescue us Oregonians by dispatching National Guard troops to use “full force if necessary” against the “enemy from within.” We asked an intrepid photographer, Rian Dundon, to brave the flames and firefights to capture the mood in this war zone, or what Trump called a “burning hellhole.”

item.title: Sorcery-related violence survivor raises awareness by sharing her experience
item.description:
A survivor of sorcery-related violence, Eki Peter of Pakale village in the Magarima District of Hela Province, is sharing her experience to advocate and raise awareness in the community.

She hopes to eradicate the superstitious beliefs held by people who perform acts of "jungle justice" on accused and tortured women, especially elderly mothers, blaming them for illnesses and deaths that have natural causes.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Sorcery-related violence survivor raises awareness by sharing her experience appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Victim-of-Sorcery-related-violence-Eki-Peter.png?w=800)
A survivor of sorcery-related violence, Eki Peter of Pakale village in the Magarima District of Hela Province, is sharing her experience to advocate and raise awareness in the community.
She hopes to eradicate the superstitious beliefs held by people who perform acts of "jungle justice" on accused and tortured women, especially elderly mothers, blaming them for illnesses and deaths that have natural causes.

item.title: Pukpuk Treaty will not take effect yet, political expert says
item.description:
Last week, the Papua New Guinean and Australian governments signed a mutual defense agreement, the "Pukpuk Treaty," which created a stir and raised questions among citizens.

In a recent discussion on the Pukpuk Treaty hosted by the Media Development Initiative, Michael Kabuni, a former Lecturer in Political Science at the University of Papua New Guinea and a Ph.D. candidate at the Australian National University, explained that the treaty will not take effect immediately.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Pukpuk Treaty will not take effect yet, political expert says appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/Michael-Kabuni.png?w=800)
Last week, the Papua New Guinean and Australian governments signed a mutual defense agreement, the "Pukpuk Treaty," which created a stir and raised questions among citizens.
In a recent discussion on the Pukpuk Treaty hosted by the Media Development Initiative, Michael Kabuni, a former Lecturer in Political Science at the University of Papua New Guinea and a Ph.D. candidate at the Australian National University, explained that the treaty will not take effect immediately.

item.title: Fa’alauiloaina le masina o Oketopa mo le Puipuiga o Faamatalaga i le Initaneti
item.description:
Le Afioga i le Kovana ia Pulaalii Nikolao Pula [ata: foa'i]
By 
LALI STAFF

Pago Pago - AMERIKA SAMOA

O le aso 7 o Oketopa, 2025, na sainia ai e le Afioga i le Kovana ia Pulaalii Nikolao Pula, ia se Poloa’iga Faalaua’itele, e aloaia ai le avea ai Oketopa 2025 ma “Masina o le Fa’alauiloa’iina ai o le Puipuiga o Faamatalaga i luga o le Initaneti, i totonu o Amerika Samoa ma ua valaaulia ai tagatanu’u uma,  o matagaluega a le malo, pisinisi ma faalapotopotoga a le nu’u e faamanatuina lenei masina i polokalame ma gaioiga ua fuafuaina e faalautele le silafia, fa’amalosia le tete’e atu, ma faamautinoa le saogalemu o lo tatou lumana’i fa’ainitaneti.”

E tusa ai ma fa’aupuga o lenei poloa’iga fa’alauaitele, i le mafua’aga ua aloaia ai lenei masina, e avea ma masina e fa’alauiloa’iina ai le puipuiga o faamatagalaga i luga o le initaneti, ua ta’ua ai e faapea, “O le malo o Amerika Samoa, e ta’utino i lona sao taua i le iloaina, puipuia ai ona tagatanu’u, ma tali atu i taufa’amata’u tau fa’amatalaga, i luga o upega tafa’ilagi, ma le initaneti (cybersecurity), e ono a’afia tele ai lo tatou saogalemu ta’ito’atasi fa’atasi ai, ma le le fa’alaua’iteleina o fa’amatalaga fa’apea le mautu o le tamaoaiga.”

Ae le gata i lea, o se tasi o mafua’aga, ona “o vaega taua o le atina’e fa’avae – e aofia ai tautua tau tupe, a’oa’oga, feso’ota’iga tau telefoni ma tekonolosi, soifua maloloina, tautua eletise ma le suavai malosiaga, felauaiga, ma le fa’avave ona tali atu i fa’alavelave fa’afuase’i – ua fa’ateteleina le fa’alagolago i faiga o faamatalaga ma tekonolosi ua mautinoa ma malosi.”

Ua ta’ua foi i le poloaiga faalauaitele a le afioga i le Kovana le taua o le a’oa’oina ma le ‘faalauteleina o le silafia i le puipuiga tau fa’amatalaga i luga o upega tafa’ilagi ma le initaneti (cybersecurity awareness”.   Ma o lea tulaga, e taua mo tagata uma, “e aofia ai ofisa o le malo, pisinisi tetele ma laity, a’oga, fa’alapotopotoga e le maua ai ni tupe fa’asili, faapea tagatanu’u ta’ito’atasi o lo’o fa’aaogaina komepiuta, telefoni feavea’i, ma isi masini feso’ota’i i le initaneti.”

Ma o nisi o auala lelei e mafai ona tausia ai le saogalemu i luga o upega tafa’ilagi, e pei ona ta’ua i le poloa’iga a le afioga i le Kovana, “e aofia ai le siakiina masani o tala, fa’aititia o faamatalaga fa’aletagata lava ia e faasoaina atu, faafouina polokalame komepiuta, fa’aaogaina o upu fa’alilolilo (passwords), tulaga ese ma faigata, fa’aga’oia o faiga fa’amaoniga e tele (multi-factor authentication), ma le fa’apipi’iina o polokalama ‘antivirus’ ma pa puipui fa’ainitaneti (firewalls)”.  O nei tulaga uma, e taua tele i le puipuia mai osofa’iga e pei o taumafaiga taufa’asese tau tupe ma nisi osofa’iga i fa’amaumauga.

E le gata i lea, o le taua o lenei masina, ona o le taua o le fa’amalamalamaina i tagata lautele “ia avanoa ma galuega i le matata tau puipuiga o faamatalaga i luga o upega tafa’ilagi ma le initaneti, e taua tele mo le lumana’i o le Teritori.”  

“Ma o le atina’eina o se aufaigaluega tomai i lenei matata e fa’amalosia ai le saogalemu o le atunu’u atoa mo le manuia o Amerika Samoa.”

Ua fa’alauiloa mai foi i le poloa’iga fa’alauaitele a le Kovana, le taua o lenei masina, ina ia mafai e le mamalu lautele “ona tausia pea o le saogalemu ma le mautu o avanoa i luga o upega tafa’ilagi ma le initaneti, o se matafaioi, e fafau faatasi e tagata ta’ito’atasi, aiga, pisinisi, a’oga ma ofisa o le malo.”

Ma ua ta’ua ai le taulamua i le fa’amalosia o le puipuiga, le tete’e atu ma le silafia i osofa’iga tau faamatalaga i luga o upega tafa’ilagi ma le initaneti i le Teritori, ia le Matagaluega o le Puipuiga o le Saogalemu Fa’alotoifale (DHS), o le ASFC (American Samoa Fusion Center), faapea ma le ofisa a le ICT (Information Communications Technology).

Ma o lenei tulaga, ua faapea foi ona fa’atauaina i le Iunaite Setete ma le lalolagi atoa ia Oketopa, “ma ua avea ma avanoa mo tagatanu’u uma, e toe mata’alia ai i amioga saogalemu i luga o le initaneti, fa’amalosia ai le puipuiga a faalapotopotoga, ma auai i a’oa’oga ma gaioiga faalautele i totonu o le nu’u.”

Section: 
Le Lali

Ua fa’alauiloa mai foi i le poloa’iga fa’alauaitele a le Kovana, le taua o lenei masina, ina ia mafai e le mamalu lautele “ona tausia pea o le saogalemu ma le mautu o avanoa i luga o upega tafa’ilagi ma le initaneti, o se matafaioi, e fafau faatasi e tagata ta’ito’atasi, aiga, pisinisi, a’oga ma ofisa o le malo.”
Ma ua ta’ua ai le taulamua i le fa’amalosia o le puipuiga, le tete’e atu ma le silafia i osofa’iga tau faamatalaga i luga o upega tafa’ilagi ma le initaneti i le Teritori, ia le Matagaluega o le Puipuiga o le Saogalemu Fa’alotoifale (DHS), o le ASFC (American Samoa Fusion Center), faapea ma le ofisa a le ICT (Information Communications Technology).
Ma o lenei tulaga, ua faapea foi ona fa’atauaina i le Iunaite Setete ma le lalolagi atoa ia Oketopa, “ma ua avea ma avanoa mo tagatanu’u uma, e toe mata’alia ai i amioga saogalemu i luga o le initaneti, fa’amalosia ai le puipuiga a faalapotopotoga, ma auai i a’oa’oga ma gaioiga faalautele i totonu o le nu’u.”
Section:
[Le Lali](/le-lali)

item.title: Newly refurbished HIV clinic to increase number of testing in Port Moresby
item.description:
With Port Moresby having the nation's highest HIV rate, the newly refurbished St Therese HIV Clinic in Hohola, funded by the Australian Government, is set to increase the number of HIV tests in the Nation's Capital.

Dr. Dora Lenturut-Katal, Deputy Secretary of National Health Standards and Compliance, said this in her remarks at the official opening on behalf of Minister for Health, Elias Kapavore.

item.title: POU TIUTE A LEOLEO
item.description:
[ata: foa'i]
By 
LALI STAFF

Pago Pago - AMERIKA SAMOA

O le po o Aukuso 24, 2025, e tusa ai ma fa’amaumauga a le faamasinoga, na fa’afeso’ota’i atu ai e se tamaloa ia le Ofisa a Leoleo i Tafuna, e ripotia le susuga ia Henry Talia, o lo’o faatupu vevesi i autafa o le latou fale i Fagaima.

Ina ua taunu’u leoleo i le nofoaga na tupu ai le fa’alavelave, na mua’i talanoa leoleo ma le tua’a a le na molia.  Ma sa na ia faamatalaina le alu atu o lona atalii (le na molia) i le fale, ua fa’asuaava, ma sa alu e moe.  Ae peitai, na o latou fa’alogoina lona pa’o mai i autafa o le fale.

E o’o atu leoleo, o lo’o iai Henry i totonu o le fale.  Ae ina ua ia vaai mai i leoleo, na tu i luga ma fa’alala mai i leoleo se paipa sa u’u i lona lima, ma fai mai i leoleo, e aua le latalata atu ia te ia, ma o le a ia sasaina leoleo i le paipa.

Sa oso atu le tina o le na molia, ma taumafai e taofi o ia, ae peitai, sa musu le na molia, e faalogo i lona tina.  Ona tago lea o le tina ua se’i ‘ese le paipa mai i le lima o le na molia.

Ae peitai, ina ua toe agai atu leoleo i le na molia, sa amata ona sasau mai moto a Henry i leoleo.  Na vave ona ave faapagotaina e leoleo ia le na molia ae peitai, sa taumafai le alii e sola ese ma leoleo.  A’o fefaloa’i ia Henry ma leoleo, na i’u ina tau ai se tu’i a leisi leoleo, i foliga o leisi leoleo.  

Sa faamatalaina e le tamaloa lea na valaau i le Ofisa a leoleo, sa alu i le nofoaga o iai taxi, e faaaoga le latou fale le ta’ua, ae ona va’aia le na molia o tu atu i tua ma se pate pesipolo faapea se apa pia, ma amata ona ‘e’e ma palauvale ma ona tu’ua’ia ia ave taxi i le le fa’a’aloalo.

Na valaau mai ai le tamaloa lea na valaau i le ofisa a leoleo, e alu i le fale e moe, aua o le fale e nofo ai le na molia, e i tua tonu lava o le nofoaga e tu tu ai taavale taxi.  Ae peitai, na amata ona tau’ai e le na molia ia le fale a le tamaloa lea e latou te tuaoi.  Ina ua mae’a le gaioiga lea a Henry, ma alu ai loa i le latou aiga.

I moliaga a Henry Talia, na aofia ai:

Faitauga 1:  Faatupu Vevesi i nofoaga faitele – O se vaega ‘A’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala ai i le falepuipui, e o’o atu i le ono masina, o se sala tupe e $500; po o faasalaga uma e lua.

Faitauga 2:  Fa’ao’olima i lona tulaga e tolu – O se vaega ‘A’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala ai i le falepuipui, e o’o atu i le tasi tausaga, po o se sala tupe e $1,000 po o faasalaga uma e lua.

Faitauga 3:  Tete’e i le ave faapagota e leoleo - O se vaega ‘A’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala ai i le falepuipui, e o’o atu i le tasi tausaga, po o se sala tupe e $1,000 po o faasalaga uma e lua.

E $2,000 se vaegatupe na fa’atulagaina e mafai ona tatalaina ai i tua le na molia, mai i le falepuipui, a’o faagasolo lona faamasinoga.

VALA’AU SE TINA LOTO MAFATIA I LEOLEO E AVE ‘ESE ATU LANA TAMA

E tusa ai ma fa’amaumauga a le faamasinoga, o le aoauli o le aso 17 o Aukuso, 2025, na fa’afeso’ota’i ai e se tina loto mafatia, ia le Ofisa a Leoleo i Leone, e tusa ai ma sona alo, e suafa ia Rocky Lavasi’i, o lo’o faapisa i lo latou aiga ma ua ia mana’omia ai le fesoasoani a leoleo.

Ina ua taunu’u leoleo, sa o latou talatalanoa ma le tina na a’afia ma sa ia faamatalaina i leoleo, le fa’ate’ia o ia ina ua amata ona ‘e’e ma palauvale lona alo (le na molia) ae e ‘ote atu iai le tina, ae to’atama’i le alii ma amata ona ia fa’amata’u i lona tina.

Sa ta’ua e le tina lona fefe, e le gata i lona saogalemu ae faapea foi le saogalemu o lona aiga, ona e le o se taimi muamua lea ua tupu ai se tulaga faapea.  Na ta’ua e le tina lona fa’afeso’ota’ia o leoleo mo se fesoasaoni, a’o fa’aauau pea ona malosi sauaga a le na molia.

Ma sa ta’ua ai foi le tina, o lo’o loma seisi faamasinoga a le na molia, ona o seisi foi mataupu e faapea foi.

Sa fa’afaigata ona taumafai leoleo e ave faapagota le na molia, ona o lona tete’e mai i leoleo ma ia fai mai i leoleo, e aua le tago atu seisi ia te ia.  

Ina ua mafai ona aveina tu le na molia, i le ofisa a leoleo, sa fesiligia o ia mo se fa’amalamalamaga o le mafua’aga na tupu ai le faalavelave.  Ae tali le na molia, na mafua ona ua le fiafia.

O moliaga na faia faasaga ia Rocky Lavasi’i, o le Faatupu Vevesi i nofoaga tuma’oti – O se vaega ‘C’ i solitulafono mama, e mafai ona nofosala ai i le falepuipui, e o’o atu i aso e 15, po o se sala tupe e $300; po o faasalaga uma e lua.

E $500 se vaegatupe ua fa’atulagaina, e mafai ona tatalaina ai le na molia, i tua mai i le falepuipui, a’o faagasolo lona faamasinoga.

Section: 
Le Lali

[![](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/dps_station_suvs_54.jpeg?itok=w30x6yQ2)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/dps_station_suvs_54.jpeg?itok=FcxLa7eD)

item.title: Australian-funded St. Therese’s newly refurbished HIV clinic reopens in Port Moresby
item.description:
The newly refurbished St Therese's HIV clinic in Hohola, Port Moresby, funded by the Australian government was officially reopened this afternoon.

Present for the official opening ceremony were Australian High Commissioner to Papua New Guinea, Mr. Ewen McDonald; Australian senator Nita Green; and Dr. Dora Lenturut-Katal, deputy secretary for National Health Standards and Compliance.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Australian-funded St. Therese’s newly refurbished HIV clinic reopens in Port Moresby appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: PNG Hekari FC pioneers new international path for PNG footballers
item.description:
The long-held dream of playing football in Europe and Asia is now a reality for young Papua New Guinean footballers, thanks to the newly rebranded PNG Hekari Football Club and the launch of the OFC Professional League (OFCPL).

After 23 years in the making, the "Red Army" will stage the first Papua New Guinean team in the OFC Pro League, opening a direct gateway to international football markets across Australia, Asia, and Europe.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNG Hekari FC pioneers new international path for PNG footballers appeared first on Post Courier.

The long-held dream of playing football in Europe and Asia is now a reality for young Papua New Guinean footballers, thanks to the newly rebranded PNG Hekari Football Club and the launch of the OFC Professional League (OFCPL).

item.title: PNG rugby league mourns the passing of Kimbe Cutters’ Ray Amos Jnr
item.description:
The Papua New Guinea rugby league community is in mourning following the passing of Kimbe Cutters forward Ray Amos Jnr earlier this morning.

Amos, who sustained a serious injury during a match earlier this season and had remained hospitalised since the incident, passed away after a prolonged period of medical care.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Restoring hope, connection and opportunity through road access for people of Upper Erap
item.description:
The long and tiring days of climbing mountains and walking long distances to access health services, schools, and markets are now over for people of Upper Erap in Nawae district of Morobe province.

These people have been isolated from better opportunities and access to improve livelihoods for about ten years.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Restoring hope, connection and opportunity through road access for people of Upper Erap appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Gunemba joins PNG Hekari FC as squad roster is finalised
item.description:
PNG football legend Raymond Gunemba has joined the newly rebranded PNG Hekari Football Club as a marquee player for the inaugural OFC Professional League, club president Vonie Kapi Natto confirmed today, October 13, 2025.

Franchise Owner and President Vonie Kapi Natto expressed immense joy over Gunemba’s inclusion, calling him a "very rare talent" and noting his excitement to join the professional setup.

item.title: Thornton: National Banking Corporation aims to dilute government ownership
item.description:
The National Banking Corporation (NBC) Chief Executive Officer, Paul Thornton, has clarified that the government’s ownership in the bank will continue to be reduced in line with licensing requirements set by the Bank of Papua New Guinea (BPNG).

With criticism from the Opposition, which claimed that because NBC is government-owned, it would be easier for the government to manipulate the management of public funds, especially while Papua New Guinea remains on the grey list for financial compliance.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Thornton: National Banking Corporation aims to dilute government ownership   appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/PC-Live-31.png?w=940)
The National Banking Corporation (NBC) Chief Executive Officer, Paul Thornton, has clarified that the government’s ownership in the bank will continue to be reduced in line with licensing requirements set by the Bank of Papua New Guinea (BPNG).
With criticism from the Opposition, which claimed that because NBC is government-owned, it would be easier for the government to manipulate the management of public funds, especially while Papua New Guinea remains on the grey list for financial compliance.

item.title: Nono Jets soar to USSY RFL senior men’s glory; U19 grand final ends in thrilling draw
item.description:
The Nono Jets of Kundiawa have been crowned the 2025 Senior Men's champions of the USSY Rugby Football League (RFL) after defeating the Woka Stars in a tense Grand Final showdown at Womai RFL Field on Saturday.

In a match that served as a thrilling close to the 2025 season, the Nono Jets secured the Senior Men’s Cup with a narrow 10-01 victory over the valiant Woka Stars. Both teams showcased exceptional skill and sportsmanship, treating supporters to a high-quality display of rugby league.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

JB Pritzker of Illinois and other top Democrats in the state.

item.title: Obituaries for October 12
item.description: Keith Frank Amaral, 81, of Volcano, died July 30. He was retired from the University of Hawaii’s 88-inch telescope on Mauna Kea. Visitation 8:30-10 a.m. Friday, Oct. 24, at St. Theresa Catholic Church in Mountain View. Mass at 10 a.m. Urn committal to follow at Homelani Memorial Park. Online condolences: homelanimemorialpark.com. Survived by wife, Gloria Ann Amaral of Volcano; daughter, Sylvia (Fertom Arquitola) Amaral of Hilo; brother-in-law, Ted Jaderscrom of Hilo; sister-in-law, Doris Jaderscrom of Tracy, Calif.; two grandchildren; nieces, a nephew and cousins. Arrangements by Homelani Memorial Park.

item.title: Diane Keaton, a star of ‘Annie Hall’ and ‘First Wives Club,’ dies at 79
item.description: Diane Keaton, the vibrant, sometimes unconventional, always charmingly self-deprecating actress who won an Oscar for Woody Allen’s comedy “Annie Hall” and appeared in some 100 movie and television roles, an almost equal balance of them in comedies like “Sleeper” and “The First Wives Club” and dramas like “The Godfather” and “Marvin’s Room,” has died. She was 79.
item.source:markdown: Diane Keaton, the vibrant, sometimes unconventional, always charmingly self-deprecating actress who won an Oscar for Woody Allen’s comedy “Annie Hall” and appeared in some 100 movie and television roles, an almost equal balance of them in comedies like “Sleeper” and “The First Wives Club” and dramas like “The Godfather” and “Marvin’s Room,” has died. She was 79.

item.title: The wrong way to fight homelessness
item.description: Across the country, cities have taken to cracking down on people who lack housing — not by finding them places to live, but by kicking them out of the places they are seeking shelter. These mass encampment evictions owe in part to a 2024 U.S. Supreme Court ruling, City of Grants Pass v. Johnson, that allowed cities to enforce bans on public camping even if shelters in the area are full.
item.source:markdown: Across the country, cities have taken to cracking down on people who lack housing — not by finding them places to live, but by kicking them out of the places they are seeking shelter. These mass encampment evictions owe in part to a 2024 U.S. Supreme Court ruling, City of Grants Pass v. Johnson, that allowed cities to enforce bans on public camping even if shelters in the area are full.
